newsitem.title: UK: British Labour party warns trade unions on strikes.
newsitem.headline: British Labour party warns trade unions on strikes.

text.p: The opposition Labour Party, strongly tipped to win Britain's general election by May, warned trade union allies on Tuesday against staging the kind of strikes that damaged its left-wing predecessors.
The party, now dubbed New Labour with a centrist appeal in competition with the ruling Conservatives, told working-class supporters to shun mischief-making industrial disputes.
Labour would not tolerate stoppages by "armchair revolutionaries", employment spokesman David Blunkett said.
The party has been out of power for nearly two decades after having been politically torpedoed by waves of industrial unrest, led by left-wing militants.

The annual conference of the Trades Union Congress has touched off a bout of tough-talking about unionists from both Tony Blair's revamped Labour and the Conservatives of Prime Minister John Major, lagging 20 points in opinion polls.
The government said on Monday it was considering ways of curbing strikes and Labour said it,too, was studying the issue.
Blunkett, in a newspaper article written ahead of a key speech to top trade unionists, proposed stronger arbitration procedures to avoid costly strikes.

"An incoming Labour government is not going to tolerate the activities of armchair revolutionaries whose only interest is disruption and who see disputes as an opportunity for mischief-making," he wrote in London's Evening Standard.
Blunkett said if Labour won the next general election, it would aim to "foster a very different climate, one of cooperation which will prevent genuine disagreements erupting into strikes".
But if that failed, Labour wanted to see trade unions agree to settle disputes by arbitration rather than calling their members out on strike.
Strikes have been on the increase this summer, with both the Royal Mail postal service and the London underground disrupted by repeated one-day stoppages.

In a hint of government action, Trade and Industry Secretary Ian Lang said: "We now think is it's time to go a little bit further, one more step, in the light of the way in which in monopoly services it is still possible for trade unions to hold the public to ransom."
Trade unionists dismissed as union-bashing Lang's statement, which newspapers said could mean a compulsory one-month cooling off period before a strike could be called.
Blunkett said the underground drivers' union and management were looking at setting up an arbitration panel that could meet to resolve problems before a dispute erupted.
He said that could be the model for a wider system.
